**Create a Vision Board**: To tackle the feelings of jealousy, start by creating a vision board for your new business. Gather images, quotes, and other inspiring materials that resonate with your goals and aspirations. This visual representation will remind you of the journey ahead, your unique strengths, and what you aim to achieve in your business. As you work on your business, regularly refer to your vision board to keep your motivation high and remind yourself of why you started this journey.

**Develop a Mentorship Relationship**: Reach out to successful entrepreneurs who have started similar businesses or have faced challenges similar to yours. Request to connect with them, perhaps as part of an informal mentorship relationship. Discussing their experiences, successes, and failures can provide valuable insights into managing emotions like jealousy and help you gain perspective. Additionally, learning from their strategies might inspire new ideas for your own business.

**Focus on Your Unique Selling Proposition (USP)**: Instead of comparing yourself to others, emphasize what makes your business unique. This will not only boost your confidence but also make it easier to stand out in a crowded market.

**Set Realistic Milestones and Celebrate Achievements**: Break down your business goals into smaller, manageable milestones. Set achievable targets and celebrate each accomplishment along the way. This not only helps in maintaining motivation but also provides tangible evidence of progress. Recognize that every step forward, no matter how small, is a victory that contributes to your overall success.

**Mindfulness and Emotional Regulation Techniques**: Develop a regular practice of mindfulness meditation or other relaxation techniques to manage feelings of jealousy. These practices can help you become more aware of your thoughts and emotions, allowing you to address them constructively. By learning to regulate your emotions, you'll be better equipped to maintain a positive mindset and focus on your business growth rather than comparing yourself to others.
